column16: that I adore Octodad: Dadliest Catch (what a great subtitle

reviewText:
Overall, I liked this game.  It was well-scripted and had some nice action scenes.  A few small issues though:
1.  Animation.  The protagonist looks like an octopus.  I think this is a glitch.
2.  Voice acting.  Overall, pretty good, but the main guy's words are always garbled and unintelligble.  I thought at first this was intentional as some sort of weird joke, but the other characters understand him!
3.  Controls.  I press buttons and my legs and arms kind of just wind and wiggle all over.  Game is still beatable, but much harder than if I could just walk and jump like if it was working.
It's good enough that I would still buy it with this issues, but fix these and it's a no-brainer!

reviewText:
One of the funniest games in the last couple of years! Yes, it's a 3D comic game. Yes, it's colourful. Yes, it's also funny for kids. Yes, the story is far fetched. Yes, the music is cool. Yes, it's not too easy but also not too hard. Yes, it's many hours of hilarious fun. Yes, the physics are good.

But you know what? The control of Octodad is a blast! YOu have 2 control modes which you switch with the middle mouse button. One is walking ... sometimes sliding ... by pressing left/right mouse for the left/right leg ... erm ... arm. The other mode is just for controling your right arm ... errr ... just another arm. While in control of your legs/arm, you move the mouse to stear it in the 3D room. The controls are really intuitive after you get used to it. Much easier than e.g. in Surgeon SImulator 2013.

Octodad is always in motion - well, it's not that easy to stay" on 4 arms to somehow hide your appearance in a human trouser. It's a little slimy
date: slippery and jelly like movement. You can grab/hold things by usiong your vaccuum arm. The arms are also quite elastic and can stretch about twice it's size when holding unmovable things. You can also throw obstacles around. You also swim totally nacked just like a real octopus in the water. And have to solve lots of puzzles and quests.\n\nI bought this game for my children
hoursPlayed: that I had to play it
voteText: too. If you like to have a good time - palay Octodad! :-)"

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wpR_gaY6YcI

I picked this game up with no idea what to expect. I somehow missed the first version of the game (perhaps due to my complete lack of knowledge on the series as is apparent at the start of my video), but going into this game I found myself pleasantly surprised.

With all the mentions of humour in this game I was kind expecting some hyped up world full of modern pop culture references where I'd need Know Your Meme open up on the other monitor or something, but thankfully we got something a whole lot better than that. This game is funny because it's stupid. Stupid in a good way. The way you control the character, the way he moves, the way he looks, the way you get caught up in a kitchen table and flying around the room in an attempt to make yourself a cup of coffee is most enjoyable.

The story is great because it is so simple. Who knew outside the world of menial task simulators would you find yourself having fun in a game where you go to the supermarket or mow the lawn? Despite having the ability to take full control of your character, as you learn the ropes of the controls you find a complete unpredictability with how you're going to find yourself next, and it's hilarious. In fact because of the strange and unique way you control the character, I found a sense of achievement when I managed to complete something, then had to laugh at myself for feeling that sense of achievement because I managed to get my character out of a door properly.

The graphics are lovely and of a very nice quality, it's definitely a nice game to look at. It's simple but cartoony. It performs great and feels well optimized. The controls take some time to get used to but that's half the fun.

It's a charming and unique game with a hilariously strange character and well worth checking out. Would recommend!
voteText: 47 of 54 people (87%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
You are a family man, looking after your wife and kids, doing all sorts of every-day tasks such as mowing the lawn or going food shopping, and taking a trip to the aquarium. The only catch? you are an octopus. You can't let anyone find out so you must act as human and casual as possible.
With fun and goofy controls to control Octodad's tentacles to get by without anyone knowing is definitely great fun, and mixed with a fun storyline with some great dialog, it was a real treat to play. What makes this game even more fantastic is the ability to play co-op with 2 to 4 people with each person controlling a limb or two! This makes for a great couch co-op experience, and greatly adds to the challenge of the game. Hidden ties help you to constantly search and explore, and the wonderful achievements give some extra challenges along the way. A thoroughly enjoyable experience, especially with a partner.

Pros:+ Cute storyline
+ Awesome dialogue (with pretty good voice acting too)
+ Unique and goofy controls offer a fun and challenging gameplay experience
+ Solo and co-op up to 4 people
+ Controller support for a great couch co-op experience
+ Challenging achievements
+ Workshop support for player made levels and mods
+ Well hidden ties to collect every level keep you exploring

Cons:- The achievement for dying 100 times in a playthrough can be a little tedious (pretty hard to die 100 times by accident)
- Overall quite a short story (if you are good at the game), however co-op greatly extends the gameplay experience.

My Score: 8/10

reviewText:
Life as a family man is good. You have a lovely wife, two childrens and wounderful house. Life is easy!..or it should be, but it's not, because you're an Octopus, but no one suspects a thing!

This game's controls for PC version, is wanky. That is why it's recomented to use ps3 or xbox controller, but sadly, I don't own one. So for the PC people, it's hard and frustrating sometimes to pick up coffe beans, pour some milk, or try to climb up slippery stairs. Some levels are easy, and some hard, but like every level in the game, has some difficulty spickes. And everytime when you just fail to do one simple thing more than 5 times, you just want to conteniue, and then you just randomly do it.

The look is cartoonish, and it looks pretty. Also the humor is good. And the game has it's moments. So if you like fun cartoonish games with good story, I recomed to buy this. PLUS the DLCs are free, but a bit short. Still, it's worth of every penny.

reviewText:
Synopsis: Will you be able to successfully blend into the human world even though you are really an octopus?

YEA!
-Fun to play
-Loveable characters
-Controll Scheme is hard to use and master, but a blast anyhow

MEH!
-How they not know your a octopus!
-Better yet how did they reproduce?
-Some things are a pain to accomplish

BLEH!
-Too short

The Lowdown:

In octodad you play as as, well a octopus who must hide the fact that he is an octopus from his family. Yes, an octopus married a human and somehow had human kids! Doing so is not easy though as you must complete your every day chores and activities without raising suspicion. The control scheme involves you independantly moving your arms or feet to move accross the area and grab things. Sounds easy but ends up being difficulty to master. Neverless it is entertaining resulting in hillarious situations or screenshot moments.

The story is quite short and only will take a few hours to complete, But it makes up for it in all likeable characters, from your reporter wife who is too dumb to know your a sea creature, the loveable daughter who is the only one with a brain who knows your a sea creature. Then you have the main villain the sushi chef who wants to make you into his main course! Oh yea there is a son in there but he is the lame forgetable one...


Verdict: Will keep you entertained through its short playthrough that should be picked up at any sale price

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong. The game is both fun mechanically, and funny in it's writing and story. Cute characters, funny situations, entertaining gameplay.

However, it's short. Much too short. I personally finished in an hour, most people seem to be getting 90 minutes to two hours out of it. It has just four short and one kinda long level, and there's so many more situations they could have put our spineless protagonist in for more hilarity. How does he function at the office? What antics does the family get up to on holidays? How's his driving? What does other kids at school say when he comes to pick up his two lil' darlings? So many dadly situations they could've put him in, and they opt for just a wedding, a morning, grocery shopping and an aquarium trip.

I'd wish I could recommend it, because I really did find it fun while it lasted. However, in the end, it's just the same feeling I got off Surgeon Simulator, a one-note game that relies on your own screw-ups for entertainment, and with much too little content to warrant it's price.

reviewText: Look. This is Tiny Octopus and this is one of my favorite games on Steam. (duh.) If you ever wanted to know the trials and tribulations of walking around on four legs when you should be on eight, or trying to keep from being made into Odori-dun by some psychopathic chef, this is the game for you. Whether Tiny Octopus is hurling apples at people's heads or dumping chocolate milk all over the carpet, this game is as accurate a presentation of what it's like to be a cephalopod out of water.\n\nKeep at it. You can do it. Soon, you'll understand what it is to be an octopus, and when we rise from the oceans, you will be ready to accept us as your cephalopodian overlords.  Just, no lemons, and no calimari.

reviewText:
Octodad: Dadliest Catch  isn't just another silly casual game with purposely goofy controls and a gimmick that dies out after five minutes.  Octodad is more than that. There's a story behind it, and a pretty nice message too.

I don't normally write reviews, but I felt like I had to for this game because I feel like I could personally relate to it in my own little way. Although this is purely subjective I believe that behind the story is possibly one of the most powerful messages about love and acceptance.

If you want to hear my conclusion of the message behind the story then read the spoilers below.

Throughout the entire story Octodad is trying to hide his identity as an Octopus in his attempt to fit in with the humans and keep his happy family together. All through the game he messes up, he's a walking disaster, he can't do anything without destroying half of the things in his path, you can hear people talking about his sliminess" and general negative comments
date: along with the chef constantly trying to kill him.\n\nI think we've all felt like this at times
recommended: and maybe even wondered if we're worthy of love if this is all we do and so many people dislike us.  but his family still love him. They still love this "Slimy" "disgusting" octopus-man even though nobody else
hoursPlayed: and possibly himself understood why. They saw the good in this kind and caring being that he most likely didn't and loved him despite his octo-flaws. I guess you could say they also gave him a reason to believe in himself
voteText: to defy the odds and ultimately reveal his true self to his family
helpfulPercent: to love himself exactly the way he is and live that happy life we're all searching for. Ultimately I believe that although many negative comments and hurt may be thrown our way by other people
votesHelpful: it doesn't make the good we and others see in ourselves any less real.\n\nI dedicate this review to my wonderful girlfriend
votesTotal: who saved me like Octodad's family saved Octodad.\n\n10/10"

reviewText:
I didn't want to buy and try Octodad Dadliest Catch when I first heard about it. It reminded me of the terrible Surgeon Simulator, which I absolutely hated because of the impossible controls. But after thinking about it, I decided to give it a try anyway. And it's one of the cutest, charming games on the market.

The story is about an octopus who somehow manages to become a family man. It involves doing chores (missions) for and with your family and while that sounds lame, these missions fit right in because well, it all revolves about having a family. And the playable backstory shows you how you became a husband and father.

It's short, lasting about 2 hours, but there are ties to collect in all the levels so there's some replay value. But most of you will, like me, probably just ignore it.

The graphics are colorful and sharp, and the voice acting is great for a game of this caliber. The music is also very well done. There are some visual glitches here and there but they can be ignored because, you know, there are a lot of tentacles to move around. It doesn't detract from the experience if a tentacle doesn't properly connect with an object. Yes, it's noticeable but not weird and you probably won't even notice if after a few times because you're too busy controlling all these tentacles.

Anyway, Octodad Dadliest Catch is awesome ! Give it some love ♥

[Rating: 81/100]

reviewText:
A short yet quite humorous and creatively challenging game.

Getting to grips with the limb control, even with a controller is no easy task, which can lead to some frustrating yet funny outcomes. The overall humor of the game takes away the frustration when you just can't quite get Octodad to control himself enough to perform a seemingly simple task without creating total chaos, sending objects flying while blubbering to himself or even getting his legs stuck through objects [and sending more objects flying because of it].

It's a game that leaves you wanting to prevail and nail tasks given to you and is enjoyable to play solo or with a friend. It's still frustrating at times but the overall humor and challenge makes it worth it in the end.

reviewText:
To this day, I'm still not quite sure if whether Octodad had on the perfect human disguise or if everyone else was just blind.

This game is so much fun. The cutscenes are cute and make you smile every now and then. Yes, Octodad is a ragdoll physics game, but unlike other ragdoll physics game, this one is story-driven, so you won't get bored within the first 30 minutes of playing it. In each scene, you are recquired to complete a set of tasks. As the game progresses, these tasks get a little harder to complete, but they're never impossible.

I've seen some people complain about the controls. I use a mouse (don't have a controller), and while it was hard to move Octodad around at first, you do get used to it. However, if you want to play the local co-op mode, you'll need a controller.

reviewText:
Octodad is one of the finest indie games that I have ever played. It even has its own workshop! The workshop list is currently fairly short, but at the end of the day, game was released only few days ago.

I absolutely loved the level of interaction you have with the surrounding environment. Missions are exciting and while being linearly story-driven, every major level has a certain sandbox zone where you can enjoyably mess around with everything you see.

When I was playing the ‘fix-the-aquarium’ mission, one story from my past came to mind. I have a friend with whom we attended the same boarding school. One day we decided to play Titan Quest (2007), which was just released. So here we are, approaching the final boss, but as we will find out later, our game was somehow corrupted, which made that NPC immortal. After failing our tenth desperate attempt to slay that mob, my friend shuts his laptop and punches it with fist as hard as he can, which also “coincidently” results in brutal death of his laptop.

What I am trying to say here is that people, who also get easily frustrated, may find this game difficult to enjoy due to complex controls and barriers towards getting hold of the hidden ties (collectibles). For the rest, if you do not mind closing a blind eye on a few bugs, you will find these 3-4 hours of gameplay absolutely pleasurable.

reviewText: Octodad is fantastically stupid. It earns its laughs with floppy physics and lots of broken props, but remains fun due to a control scheme that actually works. This isn't QWOP, though the comparison may seem apt. After 20 mins or so with Octodad (and a controller) you should be able to maneuver him pretty damn well.\n\nThere's a decent length story (3 hours~ish if you move), but there's also a lot of side content and some pretty solid reasons to go back to levels. Add in Workshop support for levels and there's plenty of value here. I heartily recommend it.

reviewText:
This game was over hyped, over praised and given way too much exposure.  It just barely lasts an hour and a half.  You could probably boost an extra hour on to that if you want to find ties but that's only if you really feel like you need to.

A lot of people say that this game is laugh out loud hilarious" and while I understand that humor is subjective I didn't find myself laughing like everyone else.  Every now and then I'd crack a smile.

Something I hear being thrown around a lot by Octodad fans and journalists is that this game is just so "fresh".  The controls are "bad".  It's hard to move Octodad
date: which of course as we all know it's designed to be this way.  Doing mundane tasks such as mowing the lawn or making coffee is now apparently "hilarious" because we can't control our character.  Don't get me wrong

reviewText:
Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a fun and fairly original game with a unique gameplay style not seen often at all in games. It manages to be fun, fresh and didn’t stop me laughing from start to finish with the only downside been that I completed it within 2hours, however this doesn’t mean I’m finished with the game I’m still ready to get the achievements and it also supports Workshop that could add hours of fun to the game.

You take control of an Octopus, if you had not gathered that by now, you walk on landing using the two back buttons (controller) or the mouse buttons, I found the controller and Mouse/Keyboard to work just as well as the other and you are tasked with numerous goals per level such as making coffee, stealing cereal, playing mini games and sneaking around stereotypical groups of people.

The graphics in the game are well presented, nothing to over the top and I doubt it would win any awards however it fits in well with the game and the game ran at a perfect 120fps even with 16xAA showing that the game is fairly well optimized to run on PC’s.

The gameplay is mostly physics based, controlling the character though levels, cant really say much more than that, most of the charm is the game is from this and the characters themselves, dim-witted adults and keen children with a mature sense of humour helps you chuckle though the entire game on top of laughing at Octodads poop sense of footing.

I completed the game in 2 hours however I feel for the entertainment value and the price I paid I feel like I already have my money’s worth but still expect me to be jumping back into the game to get the achievements and ties.

I’d happily give OctoDad a 8/10, a very solid Indie game, id love to see a full featured sequel that maybe has more complex puzzles, longer story and more levels, besides that this is one of those games that takes you by surprise at how enjoyable it is.

- Dean

reviewText:
If you wanna' be a dad, then this is Great for you. Counting that I'm Female but... nevermind.
In this game, I think it's obvious what's happening, by the Title?.
You are playing as an Octopus who is about to get married to a Human. What's funny, is that None of them notice that you are an Octopus? Ridicilous.
You have 2 children, and a wife. You have to do chores, clean up, Play with children, make coffee (xD) ...
It is very fun because you control the Octopus with your mouse and your keyboard [Duh] but it's different than any other game. Because you use your mouse to control one part of his body, and keyboard for another.
Or either you can use joysticks, and also there is Co Op where you can play with a friend!

I recommend this because I recommend this xD

reviewText:
(I should note that this was one of the first decent-looking games to hit Steam Greenlight back when it was first new, and I've had my eye on it for about a year and a half. I feel like this game would have had more of an impact if the whole Surgeon Simulator thing hadn't happened by the time it was finally released.)

In short: it's a game about an octopus who knocks lots of things over while trying to do mundane things like a normal human would. And somehow it manages to be touching.

The base game is only about 3 hours long, but there's so much polish and passion and humor packed into this game that I just can't help but say I enjoyed my time. There are several dozen clever references to other indie games and geek culture, and if that's not your kind of humor, there is also a constant stream of genuinely witty dialogue from the characters.

There are some tough parts in later levels, but there is always a way to cheese past them easily if you're observant. And there are lots of extras to find that will easily boost the playtime to 10 hours and beyond.

In all, an excellent entry into the Slapstick Physics" genre
date: and I recommend it to anyone who hasn't given this genre a try yet. Though I probably wouldn't pay more than $10 for it

reviewText: It's a neat story in a pretty short game.  Of course short would depend on your ability to figure out how to move Octodad effectively.  It's not terribly difficult but there's a learning curve.  Think of this game like a sitcom wherein you're an octopus pretending to be human and hijinks ensue.  That would be my best description of the game.  If you can pick it up for under $5 ($15 seems too high for me) I'd say you'll definitely get your money's worth.  Replay value to be had trying to collect all the ties and picking up achievements.  You can also try to get a decent time by doing the free play mode after the story ends but that would be for your own personal satisfaction.  Also a coop mode which I haven't tried but seems like some laughs could be had trying to work together.\n\nTo sum up: It's a cool game, pick it up on the cheap and you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
(I should note that this was one of the first decent-looking games to hit Steam Greenlight back when it was first new, and I've had my eye on it for about a year and a half. I feel like this game would have had more of an impact if the whole Surgeon Simulator thing hadn't happened by the time it was finally released.)

In short: it's a game about an octopus who knocks lots of things over while trying to do mundane things like a normal human would. And somehow it manages to be touching.

The base game is only about 3 hours long, but there's so much polish and passion and humor packed into this game that I just can't help but say I enjoyed my time. There are several dozen clever references to other indie games and geek culture, and if that's not your kind of humor, there is also a constant stream of genuinely witty dialogue from the characters.

There are some tough parts in later levels, but there is always a way to cheese past them easily if you're observant. And there are lots of extras to find that will easily boost the playtime to 10 hours and beyond.

In all, an excellent entry into the Slapstick Physics" genre
date: and I recommend it to anyone who hasn't given this genre a try yet. Though I probably wouldn't pay more than $10 for it

reviewText:
Octodad: Dadliest Catch
The Story
The story for this game is that You are an Octopus that marry's you wife and has children and is trying to live out the rest of his life trying to act like a actual human.  But while even trying to do this a french chef is trying to expose to your family that you are a octopus, fore reasons that are explained in the story. And to advance in the story you must do normal day tasks like....
- Go shopping
- Going to a Aquatic museum
- Mow the lawn, etc...

Gameplay
The gameplay in this game has you controlling octodad doing normal day thing's I has previously mentioned above. And the fun with this game is that you must do these things but being a octopus and having eight leg's, you will become very wobbly and difficult to control, but at the same time making it fun and have yourself laughing while playing.

Workshop
After/Before you complete the game you could always go to the steam workshop area to download some very funny mods/tweaks to the gameplay. There is not as much when it come's to the amount of mods like Skyrim or Garry's mod but atleast it give's you something else to the game.

Overall The game is worth the price and could not recommend enough.

reviewText:
A quirky and incredibly enjoyable game about trying to be a dad (but Spoiler: You're an Octopus). I highly recommend this is played with a controller.

Octodad is a relatively short but very fun and challenging physics based game, whereby you control each of Octodad's hands and feet (or are they hands too? Or should they all be referred to as tentacles?) individually to accomplish tasks any loving and caring dad would do! Such as: Attending your own Wedding, grocery shopping, and visiting an aquarium! (but don't tell him it's an aquarium!)

Octodad has a very catchy soundtrack, appealing art style (reminded me somewhat of some of the later Rayman Raving Rabbids games), and a funny yet gripping storyline.

100% worth buying, I predict (and hope) this game will become a classic in years to come!

reviewText:
Octodad is a comedic adventure game that gives very hard controls where it's impossible to play with mouse and keyboard, yet easier, but still hard on a controller. Aside from the shortness and difficulty, the game is still fun.

You are an octopus, with a wife and kids, hiding the fact that you are a Octopus in reality. So you must avoid the Chef Fujimoto,  Biologist, and run away from the annoyingly fast Hammerhead Shark.

I've honestly never played a fun adventure game with no violence in years. Even without the fighting and killing, it's still fun. This also made me slowly adapt to stealth mechanics in games, which I have barely have patience for. The controls may be hard, but you'll eventually get used to, even with a short game, you can also play mods and workshop items for it!

Overall, it's a great game and you guys should try and get it!

reviewText:
Octodad is the second game in the series, and Young Horses has had some time to hammer out and polish the big stuff - constraint physics, visual style, story - all the things that make it an indie darling. It's a short game (longer than DLC Quest but shorter than Portal) and for $15 you might argue you're not getting a lot. This game is fueled by quirkiness, relies on it, really, and its replay value depends on how efficiently you can convert its brand of humor into your personal brand of fun.

I got a few laughs out of it, but also a few frustrations. For the buildup to the final boss you're tossed into an irresponsibly designed level of precision platforming, bad camera, and a floor that falls under your feet with very little conveyance. This is a massive contrast to the rest of the game with its open environments and reliance of a more-or-less static world. I got stuck in the world geometry more than I'd care to admit there, but think of it less as a nitpick and more as indicative of the overall game - I feel the developers got a fun toy (constraint physics), decided to wrap a one-off around it, and ran out of ideas. I really do think this game was intended to be $15 worth of game-hours but they had to piece together what they had and sell it.

Like I said, I'm hard pressed to find $15 of value here. I didn't try co-op nor go for some of advanced" achievements but I don't think it would have rocketed this game to a glowing recommendation."

reviewText:
Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a game where you play a completely normal, everyday dad pretending to be an octopus. You must perform mundane tasks to take care of your family, while escaping from a sushi chef who can hold quite the grudge.

The control scheme in Octodad is where the real meat of this game is. You can control one arm and both legs by utilizing all sticks and triggers on a gamepad. I'm not sure if mouse and keyboard is supported, but I think using that would take away from some of the fun. You will really have to utilize all your concentration and hand-eye coordination to move with Octodad. Even in the endgame I was still getting frustrated at times just trying to move around, but that's pretty much the whole point of the game. There's plenty of leeway for when you need to manipulate objects, thankfully. Each level has a checkpoint system, so if you fail, which will probably happen a few times, you go right back to the beginning of the latest objective and don't lose too much progress.

Octodad: Dadliest Catch is pretty short, and can be beaten in maybe 90 minutes. Most of the levels are entertaining enough that you will want to try them again, either to beat your previous best time or to find collectables and unlock achievements. A lot of fun can be had by seeing how much of a jerk you can be with the physics in all the levels. This game has workshop support, which will add some replayability to the game as well. The graphics are very cartoonish, and work well with the story and whole idea of the game.

Octodad: Dadliest Catch was very enjoyable for the time that it lasted on my runthrough. I wish it was a little longer, but Workshop support is there if I feel the need to play more levels. Still, the devs could have added a little more to make this a longer experience. I will definitely go back to it from time to time and see how I could have completed the levels differently. I would recommend this game, but keep in mind that it will take more than one playthrough to get your money's worth.

Grade: B

reviewText:
I bought this game recently on a sale but put off playing it until I had others to play with, and boy do I not regret it. I'm sure this game is more fun than a barrel of PhysX monkeys solo, but with my girlfriend, cousin and I all having roulette control of random appendages we laughed the WHOLE way through the game. As far as user generated comedy goes, this game tops everything I can think of from recent memory.

The controls are crap but they're crap in a way that is just so amusing and ridiculous that it would feel stale if they were designed any other way.

The game is short (took only about 3 hours to beat with 3 people on roulette mode) but there are a plethora of workshop items that I can't wait to try out!

The story is touching; although ridiculous, it's rather intriguing that in the end I actually found I felt for this Octodad and his family.

10/10 would play with friends over and over until our sides burst :D

reviewText:
Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a game that ended up being quite a bit more then it appeared on the surface. The main lure of this game is its controls, which are both frustrating and hilarious. Many times I would find myself at a difficult point of the game, but still be laughing my ♥♥♥ off and cracking jokes as I flailed about helplessly. What surprised me was the quality of the story and writing the game presented, creating a funny yet heartwarming story of a man who loves his family...who just so happens to be an octopus. I espically love when the game gets descriptive of Octodad's 'blurbs' or the often odd banter of background characters. While the game's story is 'short' by how much content it has, the game's difficulty, its replayability with speed runs and collectables, the Co-Op gameplay, and its custom levels with the Steam Workshop make sure that this game can entertain for a long time.

Overall, this game is absolutely amazing for a simple indie title. The controls are as fun as they are frustrating, the story is impressive, creating well-written characters and a world that is both mundane and yet slightly off at the same time, and there are a lot of oppertunities for replayability. My only issue is with ONE section of the game which, while it progresses for the story's sake, is a change in the gameplay I wasn't too found of. But it's a minor thing at best and doesn't take anything away from this beautiful expierence in the life of a true family man (and not an octopus). (9/10)

I am a human reviewer and totally NOT an octopus.

reviewText:
There are few games that truly tested me as a gamer. Legend of Zelda 2 was one.  Beating this game with 4 people irl on roulette mode is easily the hardest thing I've ever attempted. This game is lacking only in that it has no online multiplayer, which would raise the difficulty to levels beyond cruel and unusual punishment. If you have siblings, friends or even grandparents (I played this ♥♥♥♥ with my gramps and he loved it.) I reccomend this game. But whatever you do, DON'T TRY TO DO THIS ALL IN ONE SITTING. You WILL grow to hate every other player.



P.S. If you're a sad loser with no irl friends, don't get this game, cause the novelty wears off quickly when it's just you.

reviewText: Why do I keep thinking of Portal? Is it the bright, clean aesthetic? The bevy of fun puzzles based around simple, easy to learn mechanics? The amazing quotability? The amount of character and personality squeezed from every last thing in the game? The incredibly catchy song? The short game-time with huge amounts of replayability?\nOh yes, that's right. reviewText:
I bought this game recently on a sale but put off playing it until I had others to play with, and boy do I not regret it. I'm sure this game is more fun than a barrel of PhysX monkeys solo, but with my girlfriend, cousin and I all having roulette control of random appendages we laughed the WHOLE way through the game. As far as user generated comedy goes, this game tops everything I can think of from recent memory.

The controls are crap but they're crap in a way that is just so amusing and ridiculous that it would feel stale if they were designed any other way.

The game is short (took only about 3 hours to beat with 3 people on roulette mode) but there are a plethora of workshop items that I can't wait to try out!

The story is touching; although ridiculous, it's rather intriguing that in the end I actually found I felt for this Octodad and his family.

10/10 would play with friends over and over until our sides burst :D

reviewText:
Octodad was a complete surprise for me. I thought this game would be similar to the likes of Goat Simulator - but it's actually very well made. The dialogue is hilarious throughout the game, and the relationship between Octodad and his family as well as his mortal enemy - the chef - are very well done.

This game must be played with a controller, and once you get used to the controls - the game works very well and is short enough that you'll have fun the whole time playing it.

Highly recommended for a quirky and fun platforming game - definitely one of the better games on Steam. It's not a gimmick despite what it seems - this developer did a great job on a new concept!

reviewText:
Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a game that ended up being quite a bit more then it appeared on the surface. The main lure of this game is its controls, which are both frustrating and hilarious. Many times I would find myself at a difficult point of the game, but still be laughing my ♥♥♥ off and cracking jokes as I flailed about helplessly. What surprised me was the quality of the story and writing the game presented, creating a funny yet heartwarming story of a man who loves his family...who just so happens to be an octopus. I espically love when the game gets descriptive of Octodad's 'blurbs' or the often odd banter of background characters. While the game's story is 'short' by how much content it has, the game's difficulty, its replayability with speed runs and collectables, the Co-Op gameplay, and its custom levels with the Steam Workshop make sure that this game can entertain for a long time.

Overall, this game is absolutely amazing for a simple indie title. The controls are as fun as they are frustrating, the story is impressive, creating well-written characters and a world that is both mundane and yet slightly off at the same time, and there are a lot of oppertunities for replayability. My only issue is with ONE section of the game which, while it progresses for the story's sake, is a change in the gameplay I wasn't too found of. But it's a minor thing at best and doesn't take anything away from this beautiful expierence in the life of a true family man (and not an octopus). (9/10)

I am a human reviewer and totally NOT an octopus.

reviewText:
All my life I had been empty. The doctors could not tell me why I was so depressed, and I never knew myself until today...
I needed to experience my life as a octodad.

My wife asked me to buy my sons favorite cereal, a lady had just got the last box, but that didn't stop me.
I knew as soon as I covered the lady's dress in tomato sauce and stole the last box of this cereal for my son, that this was what I wanted out of my life, this is what had been missing.

This octodad simulator has fully trained and prepared me and I feel that I am now ready for my new life as a full time octodad.

If you're feeling empty and/or depressed then what you probably need is to play this simulator (and prehaps call the depressed helpline), so buy Octodad: Dadliest Catch today, download and play it in just couple of hours after downloading!

Would be octodad again 11/10

reviewText: This game is ridiculous...and I love it. You play as an octopus disguised as a human, the name of which is never spoken, so we call him Octodad. Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a fun game about the problems of an octopus trying to pose as a human. You must try to be as inconspicuous as possible as you navigate many settings, such as a wedding, a grocery store, an aquarium, and so much more! The controls are nice, controller or not. I don't like that there is an achievement for playing with a controller, but what can you do. But this game is fun, and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
At first, i just couldn't see what it was people seemed to like about this game, it's just seemed to odd in it's whole concept and plot but first after completing it i realized why.

You play as a normal everyday human dad, doing choores and taking care of his family, doing things like buy groceries, clean up the house, take care of your kids, mow the lawn. Just normal everyday stuff, and some weird chef which seems to want to get you for some reason, which was a really confusing choice for a villain to be after a normal caring husband and father of 2 children. At first i thought this was some sort of weird 'life of a father' simulator game, it was first at the end of the game that the real twist got to me and revealed a plot-twist that is easily put there with legendary twists in games like Bioshock and Spec Ops the Line.

Even though it feels weird just playing as a completely normal dad who isn't strange or different in any manner just stick with it until the end, and it will be worth it.

reviewText:
Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a game about controlling an octopus that tries to blend in to human life. The game comes from a collage game called Octodad (Duh). The game is really creative as how an octopus is trying to blend in and do basic tasks a human would do...But after the 3rd level of the game Octodad: Dadliest Catch starts demanding you to be stealthy and avoid this and that. Then the game loses itself under generic, bland, and unoriginal stealth missions. Yet is the game still good. Well lets find out

The story (Warning Spoilers)
The story of Octodad is kept simple for the most part. You are an octopus that raises a family and tries to blend in to human tasks. Yet after going shopping Scarlet (his wife) takes him and the kids (Tommy and stacy) to the aquarium. Of course this is when the game loses its charm. Of course since he's an octopus he has a fear of the aquarium. Then after being tricked by the chef in the first game by making a mannequin of Scarlet he is thrown into the aquarium where Octodad thinks about how he met Scarlet (For unknown reasons) The chef finds where his family is and begins to tell them his secret. Octodad comes to the cafeteria where they really know how Octodad really was an octopus. The Chef tries to kill the octopus yet fails in an attempt. Octodad forgives the chef for his wrong doing. Tommy and stacy then ask where they came from and it ends with them having a laugh. So do you notice my problem with this game yet? No? Well lets get to the gameplay.

The Gameplay
The gameplay is completely mouse based. The controls are simple use mouse1 to move your left leg and mouse 2 to use your right leg. The first couple of levels are fine because your an octopus trying to go shopping, making lunch, housecare, and attending your wedding. Yet once we get to the aquarium...the game forgets its purpose. Thats the big stain on this suit. The game becomes a stealth game...a bad stealth game. Levels 4-10 are basically Hide from this and all this complicated garbage that it makes you get sick of it. Also other flaws are how short the game is. I beat the game in a good 2 hours. There isn't even much replayability to this game though. I loved the original. So what happened with the sequel?

The Verdict
Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a small yet enjoyable game. But the stealth, the length ruins all of it. The game ends right when it picks up. The game is still fun and you will still enjoy it with fun and rage once your done.

6.5/10
Passable

Pros
+ITS OCTODAD
+Creativity
+Expirementing

Cons
-Length
-THE DANG STEALTH MISSIONS
-Controls

One of those games that is enjoyable till the end, which happens way faster then I had wanted.  Lets hope there is more Octodad that can have the same charm and personality as this one.

Just normal everyday stuff, and some weird chef which seems to want to get you for some reason, which was a really confusing choice for a villain to be after a normal caring husband and father of 2 children. At first i thought this was some sort of weird 'life of a father' simulator game, it was first at the end of the game that the real twist got to me and revealed a plot-twist that is easily put there with legendary twists in games like Bioshock and Spec Ops the Line.

Even though it feels weird just playing as a completely normal dad who isn't strange or different in any manner just stick with it until the end, and it will be worth it.

reviewText:
A game where the humor comes from both the mechanics and storytelling. On the surface, this game may seem like a classic piece YouTuber bait, with it's quirky control scheme, unusual characters, abundance of physics items, and an unbelievable plot  to top it all off, but deeper down, this game tells the story of love, loss, and acceptance. It is the classic tale of the perfect suburban family with a deep dark secret.

Is Octodad an octupus?

Will Scarlet ever learn true inter-species love?

How were the children concieved?

This game, with its fun mechaincs and hilarious stories, strives to answer those questions and with them, attempts to reconcile for man's most primordial fear: calamari.

reviewText:
Sequels are always going to be compared to the original piece of media that came before it, and are thus subject to diminishing returns.

Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a sequel to Octodad. It is just more Octodad, but with better levels and is pretty much an attempt to fill in the lore of Octodad. So for all of you Octodad slash fanfic writers out there, THIS GAME HAS ALL THE ANSWERS TO YOUR QUESTIONS.

I can't talk further about how I feel about this game without spoilers, so here goes:

At the end, Octodad is finally forced to reveal that he is an octopus to his family. The game ends with Octodad and the Chef making nice-nice and agreeing to leave each other alone. And the game ends with the full knowledge of the family knowing Octodad is an octopus. This is the approximate point where I was frustrated and tired of ♥♥♥♥ing Octodad, and I was ready to quit the game and slag it off if there was anything further to play. The gimmick wore off, the novelty is gone, and there was me and the crazy physics octopus trying to navigate a fire filled room and a very deflating final boss battle. The end feels like a finality to Octodad, the official THE END on the whole thing. And I think it's an absolutely perfect time to end the series.

This is the last Octodad game. Octodad is done. As it is, Octodad is perfect and there is no need to make another Octodad game.

I will take away my positive recommendation if there is another sequel.

reviewText:
Review text copied from my blog, Sprites and Dice[spritesanddice.blogspot.com]. Check it out to see more reviews, editorials, and features!

Life is hard sometimes. Getting up in the morning, commuting to work, paying rent...it can be a hassle. Now, imagine doing all of that while also being an octopus. Makes your day to day problems seem small, doesn't it? This is the essence of Octodad: Dadliest Catch. Hilariously failing at mundane things like opening doors and waiting in line is a joy to watch, especially with a character as goofy and emotive as Octodad.

I'm quite the fan of awkward control schemes. From Katamari Damacy to Surgeon Simulator 2013, I love it when games make me stop and think about how to interact with not only the game, but the controller itself. Much of the humor in Dadliest Catch's gameplay comes from this learning curve. You control each of Octodad's legs and one of his arms individually as the rest of his body ragdolls behind. This makes simple things like traversing across a room difficult, especially when there's plenty of furniture to knock over along the way. There are plenty of input options to choose from, too: a mouse, the Mac's multitouch trackpad, and when the PS4 version launches, even the Playstation Move. Despite the intentional awkwardness of the controls, it's actually rather easy to pick up any of these inputs. I played the majority of the game on my Macbook switching between the mouse and the trackpad, though I was most comfortable using a controller. Regardless of how awkward the controls were, it never felt like I was fighting with them. The way Octodad moves is not as random as it might seem at first, and understanding that is immensely satisfying in its own way.

It's also just satisfying to watch Octodad move and...be Octodad. His facial expressions change depending on the context - whether he's tired, angry, scared, or just blinking, it's hard not to keep laughing, especially when his goofy face is flopping all over the place. Even more hilarious is the sound design - the squishes, pops, bloops, and blubs all have their own humorous charm. Even when listening to someone else play this game without looking, you can tell just how much chaos is happening.

It'd be a shame to bring up the sound design without bringing up the excellent voice acting. Octodad speaks in a series of blubs, and while they sound hilarious on their own, the subtitles make them even better. Octodad's wife and kids are also well-acted, and his kids have some of the funniest dialogue that actually sounds like it would come out of a pair of children.

The game is a little short - it only took me a little over three hours - but is addictively replayable. I almost played the entire game twice in one day because it was just fun to show the game to different people. Levels are densely packed with humorous references to other games, and each has three ties cleverly hidden for the player to find and wear.  Each level also has a developer time to beat, and just the thought of watching speedruns and all the things possible within the physics engine gets me excited. There's also a local co-op mode for two to four players, where each player is responsible for specific limbs on Octodad's body. Even when the base game runs dry, there are still tons of levels to download on the Steam workshop, as well as a level editor. I have a feeling that once players get really comfortable with Octodad's controls, we'll start seeing some crazy challenge levels that will require precise understanding of the game's physics engine.

Overall, Octodad: Dadliest Catch is one of the most charming, funny games I've ever played. It's hard not to love Octodad. We all have secrets, and while I've never personally been an octopus, I can understand the fear Octodad has of being found out. He just wants to be loved, and I'm sure everyone who plays this game will.

reviewText:
I was expecting a Goat Simulator clone with this game but was pleasantly surprised that this ended up being a fun game. You play an octupus who is pretending to be human,who also has a family somehow. The levels in the game sees you trying to do simple everyday tasks while trying to avoid drawing to much attention so you aren't outed as being an octupus. This sounds easy enough but the catch is that each of Octodads limbs is controlled seperately and you have to co-ordinate each limb to complete your tasks.

This is actually quite fun and trying to do things like mow the lawn while your falling about swinging a lawnmower as you go is a memorable experience. This game is surprisingly structured with a story and levels with various goals which is something i hadn't expected,as i had anticipated a sandbox type game similar to Goat Simulator. What really lets the game down is how short it is. You could easily finish this in a couple of hours which is a shame as it feels like they could have maybe packed in a few more levels. There is a range of mods that give limited replay value but the ones i did try i didn't play for very long.

The Good:
- fun light hearted casual game
- levels are enjoyable and so is trying co-ordinate Octodad through seemingly simple tasks

The Bad:
- very short

Overall this is a decent game and though it seems a silly premise i enjoyed it more than i thought. It's let down by how short it is and i really can't recommend buying this game at full price for that reason. If you like casual silly games then pick this up when it's on sales. If you hated games like Goat Simulator or Surgeon Simulator give this a miss. 6.5/10

reviewText:
Octodad back in the day was an interest gem that took physics and played it out in more ways than one as a gameplay mechanic. Years later after its kickstarter, we now have Octodad: Dadliest Catch. But what is Dadliest Catch? Is a sequel to the previous game? Is it a brand-new game? Or just a remake of the original? Well, it's kind of a remake to the original game, but adds more story to Octodad, and brings new challenges and obstacles to our beloved father in disquise.

(*** This Part Of The Review WILL Contain Spoilers - Skip Past This If You Plan On Purchasing This Game***)

Let's start with the story: After your wedding, you begin your day like any other, doing chores around the house when you'll be brought to a surprise visit to the Aquirium, where you'll learn about the past life and constant procautions Octodad must overcome while being out in Public. Overall, the story and overall humor is very corny and cheesy, but is still cheary and will bring a smile to nearly anyone's face. It has its charm to it. The voice acting in this game is pretty good - all the characters fit for what their parts are, and it adds life to the game when you hear your family talking about practically anything while you're tossing your Lawn Mower around like a maniac, mowing smile patches of grass at a time.

(***End of Spoilers***)

Now for the gameplay: The gameplay, well, how can I put it? There is no real Genre" for this title

reviewText:
Octodad is a wonderful premise; an octopus disguised as a human trying to live a normal life, yet failing to do the most basic of things due to the fact that, well, he's an octopus. It sounds like the premise of a great Saturday Morning Cartoon. The result the game delivers however feels a bit more like the 2-hour series finale to an Octodad cartoon, rather than a pilot to kickstart a great new IP.

The mechanic of flailing around, switching between controlling Octodad's arm and his legs works well enough, making the puzzles difficult but not impossible (although some of the arcade games are a real pain to finish). Some of the puzzles toward the end can feel really, for lack of a better word, gamey. Climbing difficult platforms and even a boss fight. The big selling point for the gameplay was that the difficulty came from doing things normal people can suceed without a lot of difficulty but are substantially harder without proper control of your body. This game is like Surgeon Simulator 2013 in the sense that the main mechanic is frustration and like said game it works to the game's benefit.

The added co-op feature also adds a bit to the replayability, having one player with the keyboard and mouse control one part of octodad while another player with a controller controls another part. The included roulette mode" randomly switches which parts are controlled by which player after completing every objective. Both result in a frustratingly fun experience for two players.

The game's main suffering point is its length; a non-completionist playthrough averaging in around 2 hours. Which is a shame
date: because the plot is interesting enough to carry you through it and the characters (particularly the titular dad himself) are all very endearing and well written (this is some of the most realistic child dialogue I can think of in a game). The game's humor
hoursPlayed: works well throughout the game from start to finish. From various references to generally funny dialogue between characters. It is also nice to see a family friendly game around. I can easily see a child laughing at Octodad's goofy antics and blubbing
voteText: or perhaps playing co-op with a sibling or parent.\n\nOctodad could have easily been done in an episodic format; a new episode
helpfulPercent: some new mundane situation made more challenging by being an octopus (jury duty
votesHelpful: career day at school
votesTotal: chaperoning a field trip
votesFunny: etc.). The announcement of free levels being added later this summer does give me hope for Octodad. I could easilly see myself paying money for a big pack of levels in this style.\n\nIn the end
commentsCount: Octodad is a short but sweet title. Enjoyable for children and adults
column16: a good sense of humor
column17: memorable characters
column18: and gameplay unlike any other. Hopefully upcoming updates from Young Horses and content from the Steam Workshop will help make Octodad: Dadliest Catch a classic."

reviewText:
I believe it was sometime between smashing my own 3-tier wedding cake to the floor and slapping my bride-to-be in the face with a live fish in the first level when I first realized that this is a deliciously entertaining game.

The storyline (albeit nonlinear and somewhat confusing at times) is a cute, innocuous little tale that playfully pokes at what could be a much darker, mysterious backstory underneath, without actually delving into it. Instead, the game remains marshmallowy and jubilant with antics such as preparing your own coffee and going grocery shopping... with spaghetti as limbs. The gameplay itself is very entertaining, and believe it or not, the controls (for which I recommend the XBOX 360 controller) contribute a lot to the replayability of this game, even if you can't seem to get used to them.

There's no way NOT to get into a giggle fit when you're slithering through the freezers of the frozen food section to get to the last frozen pizza in the supermarket. Few things are funnier than trying to climb UP a DOWN escalator when--let's face it-- you don't even have the ability to walk, nay, *stand* anywhere without falling. One thing is for sure, Octodad: Dadliest Catch reminds you to stop and laugh at yourself every now and then. Which you need sometimes. Because you're a freaking octopus. In a suit. 8/10

reviewText: This is what an indie game should be: Fun, imaginative, and something that you actually want to play. The controls are awkward, but that's the whole point! Learn to navigate as Octodad while completely trashing the room and knocking everything over is a bunch of fun. Some parts are a little frustrating as you try to master the controls, but the goofy sense of humor and gameplay overall more than make up for it. If I have one complaint, it's that the game isn't long enough. I want more flopping, flailing Octodad!

reviewText:
I was expecting a Goat Simulator clone with this game but was pleasantly surprised that this ended up being a fun game. You play an octupus who is pretending to be human,who also has a family somehow. The levels in the game sees you trying to do simple everyday tasks while trying to avoid drawing to much attention so you aren't outed as being an octupus. This sounds easy enough but the catch is that each of Octodads limbs is controlled seperately and you have to co-ordinate each limb to complete your tasks.

This is actually quite fun and trying to do things like mow the lawn while your falling about swinging a lawnmower as you go is a memorable experience. This game is surprisingly structured with a story and levels with various goals which is something i hadn't expected,as i had anticipated a sandbox type game similar to Goat Simulator. What really lets the game down is how short it is. You could easily finish this in a couple of hours which is a shame as it feels like they could have maybe packed in a few more levels. There is a range of mods that give limited replay value but the ones i did try i didn't play for very long.

The Good:
- fun light hearted casual game
- levels are enjoyable and so is trying co-ordinate Octodad through seemingly simple tasks

The Bad:
- very short

Overall this is a decent game and though it seems a silly premise i enjoyed it more than i thought. It's let down by how short it is and i really can't recommend buying this game at full price for that reason. If you like casual silly games then pick this up when it's on sales. If you hated games like Goat Simulator or Surgeon Simulator give this a miss. 6.5/10

reviewText:
I was a Kickstarter of the original Octodad, donating quite a bit after the ingenuity of the original game.

I waited a couple of years for the release of Octodad 2: Dadliest Catch, and the wait was definitely worth it.

Octodad 2 builds on the quirkiness of the original wonderfully, allowing us to continue on as a Normal Everyday Father who, plagued with incredibly awkward controls, tries to continue living a Normal Everyday Life, without his Secret Identity being revealed.

The controls have to be mentioned. They're weird, and they're awesome. At first, the controls are cumbersome and incredibly difficult to use, but after 10 or 20 minutes, after you get to grips with it, it's almost like being in control of a flight simulator. You get it"
date: and using and perfecting the movement is very satisfying.\n\nThe game itself is funny and original
recommended: and the perfect length for what it's trying to do

reviewText:
Octodad: Dadliest Catch is straight out a true original.
With polished graphics and a basic story it proves to be a delight to play.

There was one part in the last level which did get pretty ridiculously hard as of precision walking needed. This part did get pretty frustrating and I only got through it by winging it by throwing his legs everywhere till I could reach the next checkpoint. Bar this, the game was just about flawless.

Each level provides plenty silliness having you performing quite simple everday tasks.  There's usually no punishment for failing these tasks allowing you to laugh at ♥♥♥♥ ups. There are areas where you may be watched where making mistakes can add up to retrying. However, there's a freeplay mode to allow you to go back to levels and be as ridiculous as you can be.

I was not disappointed with Octodad. I was even surprised by how much fun I've had with it. The end does do something that will probably surprise you all. It is a short game but its length fits it. With Steam workshop there's certainly much more nonsense to come. Well worth the full price, trust me.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Comedy is a rare thing in games. Some developers manage it with a witty script, others with outrageous characters that help lighten the mood, but few hit that holy grail of slapstick laugh out loud guffawing like Young Horses do in Octodad: Dadliest Catch.

Octodad is just a typical guy, trying to make his way through life with his wife and two children, except that he is an octopus and he has the additional burden of keeping that a secret. Dressed in his snazzy suit, most people are none the wiser about his true identity, but suspicions rise when he is spotted acting strange.

In addition to mouse and keyboard control, full game pad support is in place. I ended up preferring playing with a controller, but both work on the same principles. By default, players control three of Octodad's limbs: two legs and one arm. By manipulating their positions in space, Octodad can walk, run, climb, grab objects, and do all of the things a normal human being does. The kicker is that each limb is generally controlled one at a time, and they are all held together with an elasticity that often sends them off in unintended directions.

The result is almost like handing a non-gamer a controller and putting him in the thick of a first-person shooter; there is a lot of flailing around and looking at the ground. It takes a certain amount of brain rewiring to be able to make Octodad move as intended, even when the necessary sequence of actions is cognitively clear.

In any other game, these would be complaints, but Octodad is specifically about being uncomfortable and learning how to function in a body that is almost alien. For some, it may be frustrating, but for those willing to put in the effort, it is ultimately rewarding to learn how to function as an octopus in society. By the end, players should be able to walk competently without knocking things over or punching kids in the face too often.

Being an octopus also affords Octodad some benefits that humans cannot reap, like the ability to squeeze into tight spots or to stretch out over large gaps. Young Horses built this awkward, difficult control scheme, and then crafted environments that take full advantage of its physics.

Where the previous title was more of a proof of concept on the control scheme, Dadliest Catch delves a bit more deeply into Octodad lore. Revealed over the course of the campaign are how Octodad and his wife Scarlett met, when he decided to start masquerading as a human, and why the neighbourhood sushi chef wants to kill him so badly. Of course, how he and Scarlett managed to have two human children is jokingly brought up but never seriously addressed.

You can't fault its originality, though. It's a game bursting with colour and personality, although the chirpy music does begin to grate after a while. It's hard not to love Octodad as he stumbles through life, and the levels are filled with cute references to indie games and developers, YouTubers such as SeaNanners and PewDiePie, and many more.

Truly, Dadliest Catch realises how silly its concept is, and never takes itself too seriously. The writing fits the mood perfectly. Some of the off-hand remarks and terrible marine biology puns are worthy of a few laughs, but the general absurdity of the situation in its entirety is the biggest source of humor throughout the game.

The silliness is conveyed well through the graphics and sound as well. Octodad lives in a colorful cartoon world that serves as a welcome contrast to the muted palettes of more realistic games. The soundtrack is similarly upbeat and peppy, and it features a main theme that will be stuck in my head for years.

Another potential sticking point for some might be the relatively short length of the story. Clocking in at about three hours, it ends before the central conceit starts to wear thin. Dadliest Catch does about as much as it can with its octopus limb control scheme, but it (ironically) would not have the legs to last much longer. I personally had no issue with the length, but those who like to calculate hours of entertainment per dollar may take exception that the main story finishes not very long after it begins.

Alleviating that a bit are some optional objectives for those who want to keep playing. Each level hides three custom neckties for Octodad to wear, each requiring thorough exploration, tricky climbing, or some interaction with the environment. Additionally, each level has a par time to beat, opening it up for potential speed running.

Also included is Steam Workshop support, so users can create their own levels, and a hilarious cooperative mode that allows up to four players to control one or more limbs, requiring an unusual form of teamwork and resulting in an even more awkward octopus than usual. Despite the short length of the campaign, there is enough in place for diehard enthusiasts to keep going for as long as they want.

In the end, I would not be surprised to hear that the Octodad community is thriving years down the road. It exudes a certain weirdness and charm that makes it stand out from a lot of other titles out there, and there are tools in place for it to live on past the point when the credits start to roll. Though it has some issues with frame rate drops and its approach to control is definitely not for everybody, Dadliest Catch kept a smile on my face for most of its duration.

TL;DR: The long-awaited video game adaptation of The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife.

reviewText:
So first thing I'm gonna say is that this game is just absolutely stupid. It's funny, it's great, but if you're not a fan of slapstick humour, you won't find half of the humour in this game funny.

Octodad: Dadliest Catch is an... interesting game just to say the least. You play an octopus disguised as a human with a family. It's like, what? But, miraculously, it still makes a great game. The co-op feature in this game is absolutely hilarious. That's where most of my 4 hours of this game have went so far with friends. Characters are great, level design is great, and it's quite hard to hate. There are quite a few glitches too, but nothing that breaks the game.

I finished the story with a very satisfied feeling, apart from the fact they don't explain at all where Tommy and Stacy come from...

The only thing about this game is that it's very, very short. Unlike a huge title game, the campaign is very short. You can finish it in about an hour and a half, and, if you know what you're doing, probably under an hour.  Imagine all the other situations Octodad could get into! Imagine if he had to drive his kids to school? Imagine if he needed to go to a meeting? There are so many things that could have happened, but didn't.

Really, my opinion is, if you're willing to pay $15 for a game that will provide with some humour, tortorus co-op and some Community Workshop items, buy this game. You won't regret, and there'll be at least one reference you didn't see in the first time playing. (e.g. In the shopping level, there's a type of pie that's called Pewdie Pie." Genius.) But

recommended: online multiplayer and other things from a big budget game

reviewText:
Hilarious and easy to digest. Laughed all the way through and enjoyed it, albeit it being relatively short ( 2-3 hours ).

So is it worth your 13.99€?

Yeeeess... and no. Technically the game is really simplistic and the core gameplay is limited. You can move your arms, your legs  and you can grab stuff.
That doesn't sound like much but Octodad manages to give you very varied objectives based on usually very mundane everyday tasks. From grilling steaks to learning about friggin kelp, everything you do in this game looks hilarious, especially if you have someone playing who is not that versed in videogames.

The graphics are nothing to write home about but they capture the games mood and tone perfectly.
Music and sounds are great, still got the Octodad theme stuck in my head after 2 weeks of finishing it, heck the whole intro sequence is just brilliant.

I LOVE IT! But is it something for you? If you have a weird sense of humour and don't mind the length of the game I'd say  grab a few friends and this game for a really fun evening ( game can also be played cooperatively, we didn't try it though ).

8/10 - Played with wired Xbox 360 controller

reviewText:
Yes; I recommend this game but with a GIANT sidenote.


The game is hilariously put together; many ifnot all the words spoken are a laugh and the many hidden jokes and gags make for an entertaining playthrough.
The controls are fun to mess around with and even more chaotic once you get multiple people involved.

It is however...way too short.
In about 2 hours with faffing about you can complete the game; leaving only achievements, hidden ties and some other side things to do which is an incredible shame.

I was surprised and sat in my chair waiting for the credits to stop rolling and take me further into the story ... but alas that was it.

So take it as you will; Want a game that makes you laugh for an hour or two with friends then by all means go and get it.
If you expect to be entertained longer then you're sadly mistaken.

reviewText:
The beginning of the game is fantastic. In an experience that is pretty much Zoidberg The Kluts the game it was a poor choice for levels to let you fail them in the way they do. It should be about destruction and not skill. The point is that Octodad controlls in a very different way from characters in other games. His steps can be very imprecise, and that goes the same for his arm movements. It probably works better with a controller, but either way the geologists make the game very unpleasent at times. Hiding has an extra layer of difficulty when you seem to bob up and down out of cover. The challenging bits should have been getting the ties and other various collectables, and not just getting through the game. Maybe have some challene levels but the game was sold on hilarious physics and destruction.

The last level in particular is very annoying as I fly off the on spots you can step on. Have some hard steps, but put amount of time to get through it or something. The last level doesn't seems to keep in mind that the movement of Octodad is the whole point of the game with it's hilarious diologue and other bits as a plus.

This game is completely worth every penny, and probably more, but there is definitely room for improvement. I'd say that the user levels would save the latter half of the game, but from the ones I tried most are still based on skill of a crazy kluts of a character.

I hope DLC is released for this game. They mentioned things like aliens, stowing away on another ship, the local mayor of the town, all things that could have some hilariously destructable terrain.

Of course, how he and Scarlett managed to have two human children is jokingly brought up but never seriously addressed.

You can't fault its originality, though. It's a game bursting with colour and personality, although the chirpy music does begin to grate after a while. It's hard not to love Octodad as he stumbles through life, and the levels are filled with cute references to indie games and developers, YouTubers such as SeaNanners and PewDiePie, and many more.

I personally had no issue with the length, but those who like to calculate hours of entertainment per dollar may take exception that the main story finishes not very long after it begins.

Also included is Steam Workshop support, so users can create their own levels, and a hilarious cooperative mode that allows up to four players to control one or more limbs, requiring an unusual form of teamwork and resulting in an even more awkward octopus than usual. Despite the short length of the campaign, there is enough in place for diehard enthusiasts to keep going for as long as they want.

reviewText:
So first thing I'm gonna say is that this game is just absolutely stupid. It's funny, it's great, but if you're not a fan of slapstick humour, you won't find half of the humour in this game funny.

Octodad: Dadliest Catch is an... interesting game just to say the least. You play an octopus disguised as a human with a family. It's like, what? But, miraculously, it still makes a great game. The co-op feature in this game is absolutely hilarious. That's where most of my 4 hours of this game have went so far with friends. Characters are great, level design is great, and it's quite hard to hate. There are quite a few glitches too, but nothing that breaks the game.

I finished the story with a very satisfied feeling, apart from the fact they don't explain at all where Tommy and Stacy come from...

The only thing about this game is that it's very, very short. Unlike a huge title game, the campaign is very short. You can finish it in about an hour and a half, and, if you know what you're doing, probably under an hour.  Imagine all the other situations Octodad could get into! Imagine if he had to drive his kids to school? Imagine if he needed to go to a meeting? There are so many things that could have happened, but didn't.

Really, my opinion is, if you're willing to pay $15 for a game that will provide with some humour, tortorus co-op and some Community Workshop items, buy this game. You won't regret, and there'll be at least one reference you didn't see in the first time playing. (e.g. In the shopping level, there's a type of pie that's called Pewdie Pie." Genius.) But
date: if you're buying to get hours and hours out of the campaign
recommended: online multiplayer and other things from a big budget game

reviewText:
Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a game about destruction, deception, and fatherhood. The player controls Octodad, a dapper octopus masquerading as a human, as he goes about his life. Octodad's existence is a constant struggle, as he must master mundane tasks with his unwieldy boneless tentacles while simultaneously keeping his cephalopodan nature a secret from his human family.

Octodad is a great example of a game that conveys a message through gameplay. In conjunction with its story, characters, and setting, the controls offer an empathetic look into the life of an extreme outsider trying to fit in and trying to do right by his family...I love that. Gaming is growing up, and Octodad is some of the best evidence of that.

Smartly built, endlessly entertaining, and unexpectedly heartwarming, Dadliest Catch manages to turn an utterly ridiculous concept into one of the most surprising games in recent memory.

Would recomend!

reviewText: I'm glad that I decided to give this game a try because I absolutely loved it. It's very similar to Surgeon Simulator in the sense that it's boasting some wacky controls and a great sense of humour. I also enjoyed the clever references and the surprisingly entertaining storyline. Octodad ticks a lot more boxes than I first expected it to. The game is plagued by a huge problem, however, and it's an issue that I actually have with a lot of indie titles: It's too short. In fact, taking the price tag into account it's criminally short. I finished the whole game in just under 3 hours and I wasn't rushing. However, replay value can balance out a game's price:length ratio and this game is a very fun experience that definitely warrants multiple playthroughs. While I would recommend this game I really want to emphasise that the best move would be to buy it while it's on sale. Awesome game overall, though. Definitely consider giving it a go.

reviewText:
It's damn good, and certainly something you need to at least try. You may have heard complaints that it's too short, but all of those complaints are completely misguided. Yeah, it's short, but it's not too short. In fact, I'd argue that the length is pretty much perfect.

It's nicely structured too. The first few levels are spent trying to perform ordinary tasks with the clumsy controls, the next few are spent performing a series of challenges to see if you've been paying attention, with the last few focused on wrapping up the story, while also experimenting with the gameplay a little.

And to be honest that's all they can do, really. There's nowhere else they could've taken the concept. They could've made a few more levels but I much prefer the huge amount of attention paid to the current levels. It's short yeah, but that's because any unnecessary fluff has been cut off.

I suspect I'll enjoy the game more than most people do, although I'm not sure why. I just find everything about Octodad himself endlessly entertaining. I haven't played any other game where even the act of moving your character is hilarious. I've seen some pretty dark comparisons to the story, relating it to alcoholisms and whatnot, but I think it's actually pretty lovely how he just tries to get on with his life despite being, y'know, an octopus.

Okay I should probably stop rambling now.

reviewText: Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a great game, with the exception of the controls. Octodad is about an octopus posing as a human father who has a wife, one son, one daughter. The only person who knows Octodad is an octopus is Chef, (Clever name I know) who spends the game trying to kill you. Octodad: Dadliest Catch looks great, The cartoon artstyle is terrific and looks absoluetly Beutiful. The soundtrack for Octodad: Dadliest Catch is just as good as the artstyle, Beutiful and unique. Unfortunatly, the gameplay in Octodad: Dadliest Catch is where things start going downhill, you have the option of ethier using a Xbox 360 controller or your mouse to play, both are just as fun as they are frustarating. I think the developers of this game made the controls this way on purpose, the controls are clumsy and hard to learn. You have to switch between two gameplay modes, The arms and legs. Constantly switching between these two game modes can be incredibly annoying and frustarating, Because if you are climbing and need to grab on to something, I wish you luck because your not getting it anytime soon im afraid. Now, for all you completionists out there there are collectable ties hidden throughout the game. Each level has three ties on it, Once you collect a tie you are able to were it whenever you want! Also, Octodad: Dadliest Catch has lots of steam workshop levels to offer including zero gravity and being tiny in your living room. Finally, Octodad: Dadliest Catch is fun, amusing, replayable, diffucult, and beutiful. With this said I give Octodad: Dadliest Catch an 8/10. (eight out of ten)
