reviewText: Octodad is a hilariously fun game. It’s got some pretty fun controls. Think QWOP, Surgeon Simulator or Probably Archery, but unlike these, the controls actually make the frustration fun. The physics really make this game golden. It’s a bummer that there’s no co-op online, only local. You play as Octodad performing seemingly mindless tasks made difficult by the fact that your mouse controls your arms and legs. The dialogue is hilarious, and with a little patience and sheer determination you’re sure to have fun with this game. It’s a lot better than flailing around your keyboard trying to hop over the finish line, pecking at keys in hopes of not killing your patient, and a lot better than frustratingly trying to nock and arrow. Fresh and colorful with cheerful music and graphics, this game is a fun play. 7/10

reviewText: I think that ths is a good game. It needs to be longer, but it's very polished and there have been no bugs that I have been able to find. I liked the ending. It was, without spoiling it, a traditional boss fight. The boss fight was hard which I, at the time found frustrating, but I am glad it was hard as it would have been an anticlimax otherwise. The implamentation of collectable ties was a good idea. In the future, it would be great to see some implamentation of a multiplayer. That would be quirky and cool though im unsure how it would work. A possibility for custom ties would be a nice addition, possibly adopting the tf2 ideology where you can obtain 'special' ties or hats etc, though I feel that this would only work well with a multiplayer version of the game. I think that the price of £15 may have been slightly too high seeing as the play-time was probably between 4 hours, though I understand that the quality of the game may have dropped if the business's costs were't covered. And besides, if they can produce a game this polished then they probably deserve to earn a good chunk of profit. After getting used to the controls, they were easy to use for what they were - this is obviously a well designed game. I would recomend this game to anyone who's looking for a casual, fun and creative game. Out of 10, I would rate this an 8/10, very good.

reviewText:
This game is a blast! I bought it after watching videos on youtube and hearing my brother talk about the game. Within the first three or so minutes I was laughing hysterically and had to actually turn off the game within an hour because I was laughing too much and waking up my family.

The game isnt overly challenging but there are some moments that make you think but nothing ever made me quit the game in anger. I would definitely give this game 4/5 stars!

reviewText:
If you're looking for a long narrative in Octodad, don't expect one. It doesn't have a long storyline to it. But this, however surprisingly, isn't that deterring to the game's quality. Yes, it may be short, but in that short time, they were able to show an emotional story of fatherhood and fear of exposure that will probably get you in your soft spot. The game has so much replay value in it's Free Play mode (Fully unlocked after completing the story), even if it's simply flopping around and being silly. And while the collectables *could* have been expanded, the ties are still a great thing to hunt after.

Where the game gets it true replay value, howeverm is in the Workshop. Young Horses has graciously given us access to the same level editor they used to make the story levels in Octodad. So now, in the future, you could potentially expect this game to be like Happy Wheels, the community banding together to make more great abnd original levels, and Young Horses giving new items and new physics to the game.

All in all, Octodad isn't for everyone. But if you like a game that you can just relax and goof off with, I'd definetly reccomend this for you.

reviewText:
Octodad: Dadliest Catch is a unique game, to say the least. Let's cover the good, first.

-It's controls are a special kind of awful, but that's the point of the game. The controls are made to be bad, as you control a boneless cephalopod. It makes the gameplay hectic and fun, while still being managable and controllable if you understand the system.
-The humor and writing are great. If you like surrealist humor and snappy quotes, this game's writing will appeal to you. Also, the titular character is very likeable, for what he is.
-Similarly to Valve's Portal series, the supply of quotes for each stage is full. You'll only run out of clever commentary if you're stuck on a level for longer than you should be.
-For a game with about four voice actors, this game's acting is impressive.
-The references are very nice, ranging from nods to other games (MintCraft")

reviewText:
I believe it was sometime between smashing my own 3-tier wedding cake to the floor and slapping my bride-to-be in the face with a live fish in the first level when I first realized that this is a deliciously entertaining game.

The storyline (albeit nonlinear and somewhat confusing at times) is a cute, innocuous little tale that playfully pokes at what could be a much darker, mysterious backstory underneath, without actually delving into it. Instead, the game remains marshmallowy and jubilant with antics such as preparing your own coffee and going grocery shopping... with spaghetti as limbs. The gameplay itself is very entertaining, and believe it or not, the controls (for which I recommend the XBOX 360 controller) contribute a lot to the replayability of this game, even if you can't seem to get used to them.

There's no way NOT to get into a giggle fit when you're slithering through the freezers of the frozen food section to get to the last frozen pizza in the supermarket. Few things are funnier than trying to climb UP a DOWN escalator when--let's face it-- you don't even have the ability to walk, nay, *stand* anywhere without falling. One thing is for sure, Octodad: Dadliest Catch reminds you to stop and laugh at yourself every now and then. Which you need sometimes. Because you're a freaking octopus. In a suit. 8/10

reviewText:
-=SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEW=-

If you have got patience, a passion for physics games and a great computer, then you should be able to enjoy this game.

Octodad: Dadliest Catch wasn't one of the usual games I play. At the start we open with controlling Octodad, as you will throughout the game. This was one of the easiest sections in the game. Finding bowties, opening doors, and throwing objects at glass panes. It was a great way to do a tutorial, but as you walked down the carpet towards your bride, it became difficult. reviewText:
Comedy is a rare thing in games. Some developers manage it with a witty script, others with outrageous characters that help lighten the mood, but few hit that holy grail of slapstick laugh out loud guffawing like Young Horses do in Octodad: Dadliest Catch.

Octodad is just a typical guy, trying to make his way through life with his wife and two children, except that he is an octopus and he has the additional burden of keeping that a secret. Dressed in his snazzy suit, most people are none the wiser about his true identity, but suspicions rise when he is spotted acting strange.

In addition to mouse and keyboard control, full game pad support is in place. I ended up preferring playing with a controller, but both work on the same principles. By default, players control three of Octodad's limbs: two legs and one arm. By manipulating their positions in space, Octodad can walk, run, climb, grab objects, and do all of the things a normal human being does. The kicker is that each limb is generally controlled one at a time, and they are all held together with an elasticity that often sends them off in unintended directions.

The result is almost like handing a non-gamer a controller and putting him in the thick of a first-person shooter; there is a lot of flailing around and looking at the ground. It takes a certain amount of brain rewiring to be able to make Octodad move as intended, even when the necessary sequence of actions is cognitively clear.

In any other game, these would be complaints, but Octodad is specifically about being uncomfortable and learning how to function in a body that is almost alien. For some, it may be frustrating, but for those willing to put in the effort, it is ultimately rewarding to learn how to function as an octopus in society. By the end, players should be able to walk competently without knocking things over or punching kids in the face too often.

Being an octopus also affords Octodad some benefits that humans cannot reap, like the ability to squeeze into tight spots or to stretch out over large gaps. Young Horses built this awkward, difficult control scheme, and then crafted environments that take full advantage of its physics.

Where the previous title was more of a proof of concept on the control scheme, Dadliest Catch delves a bit more deeply into Octodad lore. Revealed over the course of the campaign are how Octodad and his wife Scarlett met, when he decided to start masquerading as a human, and why the neighbourhood sushi chef wants to kill him so badly. Of course, how he and Scarlett managed to have two human children is jokingly brought up but never seriously addressed.

You can't fault its originality, though. It's a game bursting with colour and personality, although the chirpy music does begin to grate after a while. It's hard not to love Octodad as he stumbles through life, and the levels are filled with cute references to indie games and developers, YouTubers such as SeaNanners and PewDiePie, and many more.

Truly, Dadliest Catch realises how silly its concept is, and never takes itself too seriously. The writing fits the mood perfectly. Some of the off-hand remarks and terrible marine biology puns are worthy of a few laughs, but the general absurdity of the situation in its entirety is the biggest source of humor throughout the game.

The silliness is conveyed well through the graphics and sound as well. Octodad lives in a colorful cartoon world that serves as a welcome contrast to the muted palettes of more realistic games. The soundtrack is similarly upbeat and peppy, and it features a main theme that will be stuck in my head for years.

Another potential sticking point for some might be the relatively short length of the story. Clocking in at about three hours, it ends before the central conceit starts to wear thin. Dadliest Catch does about as much as it can with its octopus limb control scheme, but it (ironically) would not have the legs to last much longer. I personally had no issue with the length, but those who like to calculate hours of entertainment per dollar may take exception that the main story finishes not very long after it begins.

Alleviating that a bit are some optional objectives for those who want to keep playing. Each level hides three custom neckties for Octodad to wear, each requiring thorough exploration, tricky climbing, or some interaction with the environment. Additionally, each level has a par time to beat, opening it up for potential speed running.

Also included is Steam Workshop support, so users can create their own levels, and a hilarious cooperative mode that allows up to four players to control one or more limbs, requiring an unusual form of teamwork and resulting in an even more awkward octopus than usual. Despite the short length of the campaign, there is enough in place for diehard enthusiasts to keep going for as long as they want.

In the end, I would not be surprised to hear that the Octodad community is thriving years down the road. It exudes a certain weirdness and charm that makes it stand out from a lot of other titles out there, and there are tools in place for it to live on past the point when the credits start to roll. Though it has some issues with frame rate drops and its approach to control is definitely not for everybody, Dadliest Catch kept a smile on my face for most of its duration.

TL;DR: The long-awaited video game adaptation of The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife.

reviewText:
A game showing the everyday life of a perfectly ordinary human.

So said human's life includes:
Having trouble walking
Ruining his own weding
Smacking his daughter with a gallon of milk
Climbing into strange places to grab neckties
Smacking everyone in the grocery store with a unicorn while riding a segway
Flushing himself down a toilet in the mens room
Cheating on every game in the arcade
Reverse skiing
Sneaking past a group of identical marine biolgists
Sneaking into the ladies room
Running away from a crazy chef through a burning cafeteria

If this perfectly normal life sounds fun to you, buy this game!

reviewText:
I originally played Octodad when it was a small, free game made by some college students. It was absolutely hilarious and it was a very unique concept. So, when I heard that they had a Kickstarter I was super excited! I was very glad to see them get the funding they needed.

Octodad: Dadliest Catch is the fruit of the Young Horses team's efforts, and I was not disappointed. This is a game similar to QWOP and Surgeon Simulator in that the difficulty of the controls is part of the charm. You control Octodad by independently clicking and dragging each limb around to walk, and you can switch to your arm tentacles to grab things. It takes some getting used to for sure, but it is always a joy to see you flop around and decimate an entire room while people watch you, completely unaware that you are an octopus in a suit.

This game conveys a lot through it's gameplay, which is something that is kind of rare to find nowadays. The gameplay augments everything that is there, and it really makes you feel like someone trying to fit in but having a really difficult time of doing so. When things get rough, you can really feel the tension in the situation as you try to scramble your way to safety.

I recommend this game highly, however I had some gripes with it, which are mostly technical.

I found myself sometimes getting caught on the physics, like I would try to climb something or move out of a bathroom stall and Octodad would get wedged in the floor or in the wall. Granted, this is something to be expected of a character that is constantly ragdolled and puppeteered, but it can definitely be aggrivating.

I also found the game would hang frequently. This isn't an issue of my hardware being up to snuff either, as my machine is fairly powerful and I can play more graphically intensive games with no problem. This is probably due to some poor optimization and the constant physics simulation. It sometimes made it annoying to playthrough.

The Story is also pretty short, I was able to complete it within 2 hours. The game isn't too expensive however so this is a bit more excusable, but you may want to wait for a sale, as this is probably better suited for the $5 price range. It is worth noting however that there is also Steam Workshop support and a full fledged tool to make your own Octodad levels. It's kind of awesome, though there hasn't been much content made for it yet. If you are interested in this kind of thing though you might find yourself occupied for quite some time.

Despite these problems though, Octodad is a really charming, fun, and unforgettable experience.

reviewText:
Octodad: Dadliest Catch is an extremely hilarious! I think I laughed through the entire game.

PROS:
- Extremely funny
- Haven't found a game on steam like it
- Octodad's sounds
- You can play CO-OP
- The controls <3
- You're an octopus in a suit, that can put on silly glasses and fish hats.. need I say more?

CONS:
- While it's pretty funny, the game itself is a bit short.. Makes up for it if you download maps in the workshop though
- The last boss fight was a bit too easy. I found some of the 'normal' play harder

All in all, I think it's a pretty good game that can frustrate you a little with the walking (In a fun way), and in my opinion, it's worth the money.

10/10

reviewText:
It's hard to explain exactly what this game is. You're a dad in a (mostly) normal American suburb, trying to live your life and help your family. Also you're an octopus, so that makes things a bit more complicated.

I guess it's a third-person puzzle game? Maybe? But it's less figuring out what you need to do, and more figuring out how to use the abilities you have to do what you know you need to. It's difficult to explain. It requires the same sort of brain-rewriting and mechanics-unlearning that you went through when you started to get the hang of Surgeon Simulator.

It's weird. It's funny. Most importantly, it's different. I really think anyone and everyone should try it out. It's worth it.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I preface this by saying I was a huge fan of the original game and had loads of fun with its ridiculous gameplay and charm. After having completed the new Octodad, I feel like a few parts of the game design had missteps towards the end of it but it still maintained the fun and silly atmosphere it sprang from. The beginning and middle sections are fantastic. The charm of being a ridiculous octopus trying to pass himself as a human is fun to experience. The game really takes pride in the charm it exudes and rightfully so. The surreality of the entire situation is what makes it amazing. The premise is what sold me on the game originally and it stays fresh up until some bits in the aquarium.

Somehow the aquarium changes the game from being a game about the ridiculous charm of being this octopus man into more of a challenge slog  here you find yourself having to master the intentionally awkward controls. I will say as a recommendation, play this game with a controller because, while the game started with only mouse controls, the controller makes it infinitely easier to play. I feel like the challenging bits of it make a little annoying when I don't think it needs to be but there's maybe 4 sections in the whole game where I feel that way so it's not really that detrimental.

It's also nice to see this game explaining the backstory of Octodad, his family, and the chef; at least to an extent. The original just plopped you into this family's life and told you to roll with it while Dadliest Catch gives you a lot of context and I feel that's a nice change but it takes away from the charm somewhat.

The game also has loads of extra stuff you can do after you complete the main game with collectibles and secondary challenges; I personally don't care that much seeing as I was in it specifically for the ridiculous charm but to each his own. There are also few bugs here and there which had me restarting a few checkpoints but they weren't terribly bad. The collision can be a pain for sure though. Ultimately, the game is still very fun and definitely worth a look but it's definitely not for everybody.

reviewText: Octodad: Dadliest catch is an incredibly fun game, you're an octopus who has a family who doesn't know you're an octopus. All that said I'd give it an 8.5/10, great game

reviewText:
This game, is probably the most realistic simulator I've seen in my life.
Seriously, I got emotional because of realistic this was, I thought my life was in danger when they found out I was not an ordinary person, especially the part where the chef was being realistic with his butchering skills trying to cut me up I was frightened for my life, I had to have a two year break from this game, just so I could appreciate being alive in this current generation of amazing simulator games.

Unfortunately I was quite annoyed at the part where I could not slaughter my children with a kitchen knife, as it would seem realistic if I could do so, but I suppose pushing the game to its limits, forcing it to be as realistic as possible is not exactly fair on the games part,

reviewText:
I Totally recommend this game! The only bad thing it is that the story mode is short, BUT steam workshop and level edit tools compensate it (Can't wait to have some more free time to mess with the map tool).

I think my review is biased in some sort, as I'm fanboy of workshop & user created content. But that isn't a bad thing, at least for me it is incredible when devs give players the power to create things for the game.

Controls: Top! I love how you use to control the octodad, it is easy to learn but hard to dominate, making the whole game experience good to play. I've played on a controller and so I recommend you to play it.

Music: Great! I loved the main theme, the audio fits very well throught the game.

Plot: Man, I loved it, I wished there was more routine situations involving Octodad. If it was a saturday morning cartoon I would watch EVERY SINGLE EPISODE! Seriously, this kind of plot fits very well in a animated cartoon.

reviewText:
Physics-driven game you play as an... Octopus daddy.

The good :
- Physics. It's random and hilarious.
- Characters and convos.
- So many objects to intereact, andmost of them have unique reactions.
- Trading Cards!

The Bad :
- Physics and Control. It often gets irratiating when you're trying to throw something.
- Camera. wish it could be bit more movable or rotatable.

10/10. One of the funniest(in hilarity and randomness) way I've played. RECOMMENDED.


タコ親父を操作する物理ゲー。

良いとこ：
-物理挙動。メチャクチャな動きをしてくれる。
-キャラクターの個性と会話のセンス。
-色々な反応を示すオブジェクト。
-スチムートレカ

-カメラ。動かせたらいいのにと思うときが多々。

スコアは文句無く10/10、今まで遊んだ中でかなり笑えた名作。

reviewText: Some people might find this game too short for this price (normal run completed in 2 hours). But they fail to notice the steam workshop that this game has, For now it only contains few items. But after a while I'm sure people will bring HOURS of new and fun content to the game. Trying to find and collect all the different ties (without a walkthrough) will probably add another hour to the game.\n\nThe game's worth shouldn't also be calculated by length, It has a nice story and some cool mechanics. Of course the controls are sometimes a pain to handle (but you're an octopus, that's what it's all about).

reviewText: This is a rad game, that builds off the concept from the previous installment released years ago. It can be a little challenging at times, but with no major penalties for losing it can be fun for any skill level. I payed $12 and my first playthrough was 2 hours (make of that what you will). I plan to play again to collect all the ties and achievements. I highly recommend playing with a controller.\n\nI give it 4 mollusks out of 5.

reviewText:
The most heart warming knocking over ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ EVERYTHING simulator money can buy, a true tour de force that delves straight into asking and answering all the difficult questions about what it means to be human, with a lesson for all of us- Maybe it doesn't matter who you are. Maybe it's who you want to be that defines you.

Also a far better example of a functional and loving non-traditional family than gone home. Use the money you'd waste on that to buy this instead.

reviewText:
pros:
this game is fresh and creative
The games story is silly and good
voice acting is good
co-op fun
works well with a gamepad

cons:
14 euros is too expensive for a 2 hour game
you cant control the camera and that can get frustrating

final thought
this game is silly,funny and fresh from all of those gray brown shooters. But if you're only gonna beat the main story the game is only 2 hours long and for 14 euro its almost not worth it but if you catch this game on sale its well worth your money 7,5/10 good
